newsitem.title: DENMARK: COKE DEAL SEEN GOOD FOR CARLSBERG.
newsitem.headline: COKE DEAL SEEN GOOD FOR CARLSBERG.

text.p: Danish brewer Carlsberg's new joint venture with the Coca Cola Company in Denmark and Sweden was seen by analysts on Tuesday as strengthening the brewer's position regionally.

"The deal with Coca Cola will indubitably strengthen Carlsberg in the Nordic market and I reckon that Norway will shortly sign up for participation. Looking further ahead we will probably also see Finnish Cola taking part in the venture," one dealer told Reuters.
Carlsberg and Coca Cola said earlier they would jointly make and distribute Coke and other soft drinks in Denmark and Sweden.
The partners would start by setting up a new Coca Cola Nordic Beverages A/S (CCNB) holding company, 51 percent owned by Carlsberg and 49 percent by Coca Cola with headquarters in Copenhagen.
CCNB would run reorganised Danish and Swedish units, with Swedish distribution handled by the local Falcon Breweries, in which Carlsberg holds a 50 percent stake.

"Falcon has not at present the most extensive distribution network in Sweden, so the deal will mean an improvement here, giving both Coca Cola and Falcon a better penetration of the market to the advantage of both parties," another analyst said.
The analysts, who declined to be named, agreed that the joint venture would mean a solid long-term improvement to Carlsberg's bottom line but had no precise forecasts.

"The deal will have no immediate effect on Carlsberg earnings, but there can be no doubt that in the long run there is a considerable growth potential in the Swedish market. This means that the venture will prove positive," one analyst said.
